column1: Owings Mills is an unincorporated community and census-designated place in Baltimore County
column3: United States. It is a suburb of Baltimore. The population was 30
column4: 622 at the 2010 census. Owings Mills is home to the northern terminus of the Baltimore Metro Subway
column5: and housed the Owings Mills Mall until its closure in 2015. It is also home to the Baltimore Ravens' headquarters facility. In 2008
column6: CNNMoney.com named Owings Mills number 49 of the "100 Best Places to Live and Launch".

column1: Owings Mills is served by the Baltimore County Public Schools system. Schools include New Town Elementary
column4: Timber Grove Elementary in adjacent Reisterstown
column8: and New Town High. There are also several private schools in the area
column10: a Pre-K–12 school and Garrison Forest School
column11: also a Pre-K–12 school.  McDonogh School is co-ed while Garrison Forest is all girls.

column1: Owings Mills is home to a satellite branch of the three campuses of the Community College of Baltimore County system (CCBC) (Dundalk
column2: Essex and Catonsville) and a branch of the ITT Technical Institute. Stevenson University (formerly Villa Julie College)
column3: opened its Owings Mills campus in 2004
column4: an addition to its original Stevenson campus nearby to the east.

column1: Owings Mills is home to approximately a dozen major shopping centers and numerous office buildings. In the center of Owings Mills was Owings Mills Mall
column2: an enclosed shopping mall. The mall
column4: once featured more than 150 stores. The mall closed in 2015
column6: and is now set for redevelopment as a town center similar to Hunt Valley Towne Centre.

column1: Many nationally known organizations and businesses call Owings Mills home
column9: and Maryland Public Television studios (formerly the Maryland Center for Public Broadcasting). A large manufacturing complex dates to 1926 as the site of Maryland Baking Company
column10: and then starting in 1957 housed Maryland Cup (see Sweetheart Cup Company)
column11: the Fort Howard Paper Corporation (see Georgia-Pacific)
column12: and finally the Solo Cup Company

column15: Foundry Row. The first store to open in Foundry Row was Wegmans
column16: which launched in September 2016.The TV program Wall $treet Week with Louis Rukeyser was produced by Maryland Public Television at its studios in Owings Mills; many viewers became familiar with the town as the program's mailing address. Others became familiar with it as the mailing address of the weekly automotive series MotorWeek. Local roads can often be seen on the program.

column1: The Irvine Nature Center moved to a property here

column1: The abandoned Rosewood Center is in Owings Mills
column2: but trespassing is strictly forbidden due to high asbestos levels. It was used as a training location for the Maryland state police until 2014
column3: when a police officer in training was shot and killed on the location during training. Rosewood is also the location for the film The Institute.  Stevenson University recently acquired Rosewood and plans to expand its campus on the property.
